Email is the preferable method for receiving Obituaries (and the only method on Saturday, Sunday and Holidays), they can be sent to Obit@delcotimes.com (Feel free to call and confirm that we’ve received the email)

Obituaries will continue to visually look the same as they currently do, but you will no longer be restricted in what you can say (ex. As much Family can be listed as you’d like; Wording like “Went to rest with the Lord” is now permissible)

Other:

There is a cost for each obituary. Pricing and payments are only available Monday through Friday, 8:30 am to 4:00 pm. All weekend and holiday submissions will be provided a cost the next business day.

Exceptions:

All New accounts, Out of State Funeral Homes and Private Parties will require prepayment upon approval of the obituary. Weekend and Holiday staff are not authorized to set up a new account or process payments

Deadline for the above is before 4:00 PM Mon – Fri. only (Holiday schedules may vary).

Prepayment required submissions will be handled on the very first business day following the weekend and/or holiday schedule. A complete name, address and best contact phone number are required upon submittal of your obituary request to set up your account. A proof will then be emailed for review but placed on hold until payment is received.

Greg Davis doesn’t mind being in the background. His focus has always been on the music first. This guitar-playing journeyman has played from Wildwood to Japan and with such local Philly icons as Kenn Kweder, Beru Revue, David Uosikkinen of The Hooters as well as gigging solo, in duos and trios for the past 30 years.

“I have a burning desire to play music. I figured out a way to get out there and play,” said the Swarthmore music man who just finished a gig at World Cafe Live that featured a Philly all-star line-up including Jeffrey Gaines, Tommy Conwell and the Soul Survivors playing Uosikkinen’s “In the Pocket” series of Philly originals.

Davis caught the music bug at an early age. “I got a guitar at eight-years-old and my first paid gig – a bar mitzvah – at 11. It was just a guitar and drums. We played all original music.”

The burgeoning guitarist improved his licks by studying with noted South Philadelphia guitar teachers Pat Martino and Joe Sgro. After high school, Davis attended the prestigious Berklee School of Music in Boston.

It was a summer gig in Wildwood at a club called the Oceanic that prevented Davis from returning for his third year of college. “It was a steady gig in the summer of ’79 and I never got back,” recalled Davis. “I’ve come a full 30-year circle. For the last six summers I’ve been playing weekends at the Pier 6600 Hotel in Wildwood Crest.”

Straight from Wildwood, Davis headed to South Street where he became part of the seminal local music scene of the early 80s. He was recruited by Kweder to be one of the Secret Kidds.

“Basically I saw an extremely gifted and fully developed artist at the very young age of 21,” said Kweder, who will perform with Davis and the Men from WAWA at the Tin Angel on Nov. 21. “[He’s] as dead serious about music as some zealots can be about the bible. Charisma and lightning in a bottle, all wrapped up in one.”

Kweder and the Secret Kidds played the clubs and cabarets in Philadelphia as well as in New Hope, Brandywine, Emerald City in New Jersey…anywhere within a 50 mile radius of the city. They also got local radio play. “The club scene was pretty healthy in Philly. It was a great time for making music…so much fun and energy,” remembered Davis.

Bob Beru was the events manager for the band and after a successful two-year run, Kweder’s band basically morphed into Beru Revue. Davis became best known as the guitar player in Beru’s theatrical rock review that entertained Philly music fans throughout the 80s.

“I met Greg in 1978 when I was working with Kenn Kweder. Kenn refreshed the Secret Kidds with a new kid on the scene from the Berklee Music School. Even at that time Greg could turn your head with his playing,” said Beru who considers Davis a good friend.

“When I thought of taking a stab at performing, Greg was the first person to sit down and take me seriously. ‘King of England’ was the first of many collaborations.”

Although well versed in rock, Davis brought what Beru calls “a classically trained appreciation of jazz and fusion” to his guitar playing.

Newly-appointed WMMR mid-day man Pierre Robert caught Beru’s act at the East Street Cafe in Upper Darby and instantly became a rabid fan and promoter for the band. “He fell in love with the band and got WMMR on our side,” said Davis. “We went from playing before 60 people to 600.”

Davis continued to play with Kweder and Beru Revue and host what has become known as “the longest running jam session in the city” at JC Dobbs.

Davis played in the house band known as the Last Minute Jam Band that jammed every the Tuesday night at the venerable Dobbs from 1986 to 1996. Scores of area and national musicians would show up week after week to play with Davis on guitar, Wally Smith on keyboards, Michael Radcliffe on bass and George Manney on drums.

“It was a place where musicians would hang out and some would play,” said Manney, who made a documentary of those heady days called “Meet Me on South Street” which is archived at the Rock ‘n’ Roll Hall of Fame in Cleveland.

“Members of Yes and Bon Jovi would hang out and players included Ace Frehley from Kiss, Spencer Davis, members of Cinderella and Robert Plant’s touring band. Although we never missed a Tuesday night, one night in 1989 we started an hour later so Nirvana could play. This was right before ‘Smells Like Teen Spirit’ came out.”

In the latter part of the 90s, Davis ended up playing a long term gig in Nagoya, Japan. “I went from playing the Atlantic City circuit to playing a gig in Japan. Two months turned into six years,” recalled Davis. “I played mostly cover songs at the Hotel Hilton in Nagoya in a band called Christina and the Americats.”

Davis returned to the area and rekindled old musical friendships. He continues to play with Kweder, Beru and Uosikkinen. It’s a fraternity of rockers he’s proud to be a part of.

“It’s a friendly conglomerate of musicians. There’s a lot of water under the bridge between us all. I’ve really gotten to know the guys more,” Davis said.

Davis continues to ply his trade in his own band reincarnations such as Cross Town Traffic and the Greg Davis Trio. He’s released his first solo CD called “Parallel Universe” featuring five original tunes with Ronny Crawford of The Daves and Lisa Loeb fame on drums, the ubiquitous Chico Huff on bass, and longtime Dobbs compadre Wally Smith on keyboards.

These days he’s happy to be teaching and playing guitar professionally.

“I’m thankful to make a living and raise a family playing music. And I’m still excited about making music.”

Beru Revu plays “One More Time” at World Cafe Live Saturday, Nov. 17, 8:00 pm

Kenn Kweder and the Men from WaWa Play the Tin Angel, Wednesday, November 21
